Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Story: I had just moved into the apartment complex last week, and today, I finally had a free afternoon. I baked a small chocolate cake, hoping to introduce myself to the neighbors and make a good impression. As I was about to step out with the cake, my phone buzzed—a new delivery order had come in. The address was just two buildings over, and the customer had left a note: “Please deliver within the next 30 minutes—groceries needed for dinner guests tonight!” I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. If I left now, I could deliver the groceries on time, but I’d miss the perfect window to catch my neighbors at home. If I waited to meet them, I’d risk being late and disappointing a customer who was counting on me. I stood in the hallway, cake in one hand, delivery bag in the other, torn between being the friendly new neighbor and the reliable delivery person. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which role to put first.
